SP.P: I believe it did; I may venture to assue you it did, to tolerable account, as you say, tho' you predicted otherwise; it made my pillow for me; yes, yes, thank heaven, I'm easy; I've laid down my cares.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: And taken up content. What a happy fellow are you, friend Andrew!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: But I tell you you're mistaken, I am not a happy fellow; I would not be thought happy; the world's too wicked for an honest man to be happy or con∣tented in it.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: But you are out of the world; you are settled in a peaceful retreat, in rural tranquillity, cultivating your own acres, enjoying your own produce.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Blood and fire, I tell you other people are enjoying my produce; my servants are embezzeling my pro∣perty, my neighbours are destroying my game, the vermin are laying waste my granaries, and the rot is making havock with my sheep; and how the ven∣geance then can I be happy?

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: By bearing every thing with a patient mind.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Patient! I am patient to a fault.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: By reflecting, when your servants or neighbours molest you, what an examplary young man you are blest with for a son.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Yes, yes, the boy's as good as his neighbours.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: I never heard so universal a good charcter.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: 'Tis a sober, frugal lad, that's the truth on't.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: So accomplish'd a genius, so distinguish'd a taste for the fine arts.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: For the fine arts! that's rather too much, I know no art Jack has but setting trimmers, worming pup∣pies, and making fowling nets.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Your son, friend Addrew, is not like the present frippery race of young men; he is a man of sound principle and good morals; no libertine, no free-thinker, no gamester.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Gamester indeed! I'd game him, with the devil to him.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: He has more elegant resources: The woman must be happy who can engage his affections.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I wish your ward Miss Fairfax was of your opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Are you sincere?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHAE.
SP.P: Why to be sure I am. Don't I know she'll have a very considerable fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: A fig for her fortune—here's my hand—so the young folks can like each other, and Mr. Manlove is consenting—

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Who? who is consenting? Mr. Manlove?

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Ay surely; I'm afraid we do not rightly understand each other: Which of your sons are you speaking of?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Which of my sons am I speaking of! the only one I ever do speak of; the only one which I acknowledge, Jack. You cou'dn't think me such a fool to recommend that puppily pig-tail'd ape, with his essences and pulvilios; that monkey, whom my silly brother sent to see the world, with his grand tour, and his pictures, and his impertinencies? No—I tell you once for all, I've done with him; he has dropt my name and I my nature; let him that christen'd him anew, keep him; I have done with him.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: You shock me to hear you say so.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: What, shan't I speak of my own son as I think fit?

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Yes, if you speak as a father shou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: And who's the judge of that? Have you a son? Are you a father? No, you are a guardian: Heaven help the poor young woman that's your ward. Marry her to Charles Manlove! marry her to her garters sooner, and tye her up upon the curtain rod, 'twere a better deed. And what know you of the fine arts? Are you a painter as well as your ward here? I see no tokens of it; the London 'Prentice, and the March to Finchley, seem to be the sum total of your collection—His taste, it seems, has captivated you; his taste for what? for Camblets, for Cafoys, for Manchester and Norwich commodities? There lies your learning; those are your universities.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Andrew Nightshade, Andrew Nightshade, recol∣lect yourself: We'll converse when you are cool: I talk to no man in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I in a passion? 'Tis the first time I was ever told so, and shall be the last, from you at least—Here, Gregory, where are you:—I'll be gone this instant; I'll have my things pack'd up; I'll rid your house, at least, of one passionate man. I in a passion? I that never lost my temper—But your servant, Sir; your servant, Mr. Stapleton: Perhaps you'll say I'm in a passion now. Here, Gregory! why Gregory!

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! of a certain, Andrew, thou'rt a ridi∣culous old fellow. If I had an acquaintance with the poets, I would get them to exhibit thy humours on the stage; 'twould be a diverting scene, and no bad moral.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Here's a fine storm; he's calling for his servants to pack up his things; he vows he'll quit the house immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: A happy resolution. What a snapdragon it is! No Yorkshire housewife in her washing-week can be more peevish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: I wish he was out of the house; I cannot bear to have your peace annoy'd.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: My peace! You have had a visitor, Laetitia.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: A brother artist, and a friend of Mr. Manlove's. I declare I've lost my heart to him.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Then I deny that he's a friend of Mr. Manlove's.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, he is the prettiest man! so candid, so intelligent; full of his art, and glowing warm with all that taste for the antique, which true genius is sure to gain by travel.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Ay, ay, I understand you; he's been praising your performances.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I own it; but what flatters me above all, he com∣mends your portrait exceedingly; I shall proceed in it with twice the spirit I began.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: He has turned her head with flattery; the grace of Raphael, the design of Michael Angelo, Titian's warmth, and Corregio's beauty, centre all in her un∣rivall'd compositions!

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Hey-day! where learnt you all this gabble? here's a pack of names for a citizen's wife to get by heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Do you think I've clean'd her pallet then for nothing? The doctor's Merry-andrew knows the names of his drugs, or he's not fit for his place. We are going this instant upon a visit of virtu to Mr. Manlove's: This young painter speaks in raptures of his collection: He has some pictures, which are said to be inimitable.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Dear Sir, I hope you've no objection. He has talk'd to me so much of a Lucretia by Guido, that I am dying to visit her.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: I shou'd doubt if Lucretia wou'd do as much for you. I hardly think this visit is in rule.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: It is done every day; half the town has been there: I go there as a student—besides, Mrs. Stapleton goes with me.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Well, well, I am no critic in these matters, enter∣tain yourselves and you have my free leave. Much pleasure to you both—your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Come, my dear madam, the light still serves us; let us lose no time.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Now the duce fetch this madcap brother of mine, what a twitter has he thrown me into! I can settle to nothing: Madam and her sham-painter have made a fine disorder in this room. I don't know any use these geniuses are of, but to put every thing out of its place. Ah! is it you?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Hush, hush! compose yourself; you had like to have ruin'd all: Why didn't you send Gregory to the street's end, as you agreed?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Lud, I'm in such a flutter—I don't know, I'm frighted. Is he here?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Ready: Prim'd high with brisk Champagne: The rain'd is laid; you have the fire; touch it, and off it goes.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Fire! I've no fire about me. Did the servants see you?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: No; Gregory let us in, and has the young 'Squire now in keeping: There never was so fortunate a mo∣ment. Hark! he's at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Hist! Lawyer—Pickle—Bully-Jack!—shall I come in?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: He must come in; slip out a moment 'till I prepare him, and then—Remember, Lucy, he is Mr. Man∣love here, and yourself Laetitia. Go your ways. (Exit Lucy.) Now, my lad of glory, I shall show you a phaenomenon, a star of the first water.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Water! I scorn it: Give me wine: There's honesty in that, and wit and love. I'm monstrously in love—but where's the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Oh, she's at hand, and half your own already. I've been preaching to her—Miss, says I—

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Rot your says I! who cares for what you say: Show me the girl: I want no lawyer in this case; Cham∣pagne's my counsellor. You are a blockhead, Dibble, and a flincher: I'm for all the game; fee'd on both sides, boy; a bottle in my right hand, and a bottle in my left; double-charg'd, at heart and head; one for courage and t'other for invention. Pooh! my brother's a fool to me; his coat was never in such company before. Where is the lady, I say? I must see the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Well, well, be patient; you shall see the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P:
Ay, this puts every thing in motion: Now the world goes round: It has found its legs at last, and dances
like Plough-Monday. Drown it, 'twas asleep before. What's all this lumber for (stumbling over the Easel) The devil! who are you? (speaking to the Layman) what's your profession? An easy, slender, dangling figure, and as much of a gentleman as most you shall meet.—The piggins! now I smoak the jest: She paints. Oh damn it! she's an artist—That won't do; there's no standing that; I must overturn all this trumpery: I shall soon tumble you out of the room, my dear—your reign's a short one, take my word. Ay, here she comes!

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Mr. Manlove, this is Miss Fairfax. Miss, this is Mr. Manlove.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Madam, behold the fondest of your slaves. My friend here Lawyer Dibble has inform'd you that my name is Manlove, and he tells me you are call'd Miss Fairfax. Be it so; if he tells a lie, he is not the first of his profession who has so done. If you should think that I am ratherelevated and in the air, I won't deny it; Champagne, you know, is a searching liquor, and my scull is none of the deepest; but if you suppose that I am so blind as to overlook your beauties, or my own perfections, you are not the person I take you for. Dibble, come hither, make the Lady acquainted with some of my good qualities. Discuss.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, what need? the good qualities of Mr. Manlove are in every body's mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Deuce take me now, if that is any flattery to me.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: I told you, Madam, what a modest young gentle∣man he was.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Oh, you're a precious devil. Be pleas'd to tell the Lady likewise what a brave estate I have got; such things come naturally from a lawyer's mouth; tell her what it is, and where it lies: Drown me, if I know where to find an acre of it.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Oh, never name estate when Mr. Manlove's in the case: Your person, air, address—

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Madam, you do me honour. 'Egad, I shall have no occasion for courtship.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Your genius, taste, accomplishments—I myself have some small turn for painting—

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Yes, and I should like you as well without it.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: But you, I dare say, are a master-hand; and poetry, no doubt, is full as much your own.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Faith, there's not much to choose between 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: But then your education—one may see that you have travell'd.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Oh, yes, that's very visible.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Well said, lawyer—She has a damnable clack.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I should be delighted to hear an account of your travels: I dare say you have met many singular ad∣ventures.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: A thousand; but I have taken an oath never to speak of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Oh, you must conquer such scruples. What, ad∣vantages has your uncle's bounty given you, Mr. Manlove, over that poor lad in the country!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: And yet I'd rather hear one kind word said of that poor lad in the country, than a whole volume of Mr. Manlove's praises. I'm hipp'd, whenever I hear the subject mentioned.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Make up to him, Lucy, or he's lost. Jack Night∣shade, what are you about? one bold attack, and she's your own.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: It may be so; but you must know I have a kind of partiality for that same country lubber, Jack Night∣shade; and 'till I can find a Lady, who will prefer him to his brother, I will remain as I am; so there's an end of the matter, d'ye see, and no harm done. Madam, I'm your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: So finishes the chapter of husbands. I thank you for your scheme.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Thank yourself for your folly. What possest you with the thought of touching upon the lad in the country? how could you be so slippant?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: What does it signify? He is too cunning to be caught with chaff; e'en drop your project.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: No, let despair go hang. I am not easily repuls'd: Take courage, and commit yourself to me; I have resources yet you know not of. Come, Lucy, you shall see my genius rises on defeat.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P:
It is time to take off the mask; I have seen and heard enough: She who can captivate both eyes and
ears at once, is irresistable; Miss Fairfax is so com∣pos'd, that she has beauty enough to blind our under∣standings, if she wanted wit; and wit enough to blind our eyes, if she wanted beauty. I will go to her in this habit once again, and solicit an interview for Mr. Manlove: If she readily grants it, I will avail myself of her compliance, and instantly disclose myself—if not—But what, in the name of wonder, have we got here: Ha, ha, ha! my Paris suit, by all that's brilliant; the very chef d'oeuvre of the superlative Mons. Le Duc: That coat was made for grand occasions; it escorted me to the nuptials of the great Count d'Artois; it has now the honour to attend the revels of the illustrious Jack Nightshade.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK
SP.P: Ay, and had I been willing, it might have assisted at another wedding: 'Egad, it might have carried off a fine girl, and one of the first fortunes in the city.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I should have thought your scenes had rather laid amongst the girls of freedom, than of fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: This lady, Sir, had both. Swear to me you'll be secret, and I'll tell you where I've been.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Nay, Jack, you'll trust me sure without an oath; you know I am no tell-tale. Where have you been?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: You'll scarce believe it; where on all this earth but to the very house, where old Surly boots sets up his rest!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: To Mr. Stapleton's?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: To the enemies head quarters: A high stroke!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: And what carried you thither?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: A girl: The wench I told you of.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But what sort of a wench? I don't understand how any girl could carry you to Mr. Stapleton's.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: No! She'd have carried me any where; all the world over: She is ready to set out on her travells.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: And her name is—

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Fairfax.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Laetitia Fairfax.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: What is it you have been doing? I am much in∣terested in this lady's good opinion, and if you have done or said any thing to offend her—

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Offend her! Zooks, if you had heard how mere a country whelp she made of me, you wou'd own I had most reason to be offended of the two.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Still I don't understand you; you tell your story so confusedly, I can make out nothing from it.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Tell it yourself then, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: But this precaution I must give you, Jack, not to go upon that ground again; keep your sallies within proper bounds, and direct them to proper objects. Miss Fairfax is a lady for whom I have the tenderest esteem; have a care therefore, young man, how you affront her as you value my resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Whuh!

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: Sir, Mr. Manlove requests your company at his chambers immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I attend him—Brother, I am serious—Hitherto I hope no mischief has been done; but I expect that you observe what I have told you, and be more prudent for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: And be a prig like you—Oh, you shall smart for this; I'll curry your fine hide. Now would I give both ears from off this head, if I could make the girl but fairly jilt this puppy, and revenge myself upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Squire!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Ah, Dibble, I have made myself a precious blockhead.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: What, in the penitentials? Is the Champagne cloudy?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Vexation sobers me like a wet napkin. Oh, if I cou'd see the girl again!

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Do you wish it?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Wish it! I'd crawl to Scotland on my knees; nay more, I'd live there all my days, so I could bilk this elder brother with Miss Fairfax.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Say you so, Squire? This betters my best hopes. Follow me once more to Mr. Stapleton's: Take courage, and my life upon't the lady is your own.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Have with you then; I'm ready; come along.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Hold, not so fast—the old lion may be in his den. Give me one quarter of an hour's law, and then if we miscarry, crop these ears and nail them up like vermin to your walls.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Agreed! I take you at your word. (Exit Dibble.) Now, my fine brother, if I catch you on the hip I'll give your pride a rall; I'll shew you that a clown may have a courtier's cunning. Hey-day! who comes here?
SP.STAGE: Mrs. STAPLETON and LAETITIA, usher'd in by FREDERICK.

SP.SPEAKER: FREDERICK.
SP.P: I beg pardon, Sir, I thought you was gone out: These ladies are desirous of seeing the pictures, and I was conducting them to the room.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: I will take that honour on myself Go before and open the windows. (Exit Fred.) You are fond of paintings, ladies; I am glad it is in my power to entertain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: You are the owner, Sir, of this admirable collection. Your name is Manlove.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: At the service of the ladies always. I'll pass a few of lawyer Dibble's airs upon them—I'm in a rare cue.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: What do they mean by talking up this young man? He has a miserable address: I see very little of the man of fashion about him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: I cannot say much for his person to be fure

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P:
She has fixt her eyes upon me; she is taken with my person and address—Don't you find it rather cold, ladies?
—I wish there was a fire in the room, that I might give her a taste of my breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: The public is much bound to you for giving them access to your collection.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: If the public found no more amusement in them than I do, they might hang in the dark till doom's-day.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: You jest, I believe: Is it possible, after taking such pains in procuting them, you can have no enjoyment in the possession of them?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Even so, Madam; they resemble matrimony in that respect; the pursuit is the pleasure. But come, ladies, the room is ready, and I'll shew you the way.—What the devil does that old Duenna come for?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Is this the accomplish'd Mr. Manlove? He seems in a strange humour: Are you sure he is perfectly sober? I declare I scarce like to follow him.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK
SP.P: Ladies, this is the way: Indulge me with the honour of your hand.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: An Apartment magnificently furnished with pictures.
JACK introducing Mrs. STAPLETON and LAETITIA.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: There, Ladies; there they hang: A jolly crew or 'em. Old Ladies in furrs and furbelows up to their throats, and young ones without a rag to cover 'em: These painters are but scurvy taylors; they'll send a goddess into the world without a cloud to cover her: There are some pretty conceits go with their histories, but they will speak for themselves; I am but little in their secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: What a blaze of beauty! there's the Tian Venus; heavens! what a form! what brilliant hues! But look, dear Madam, here is grace and dignity: Guido's Lucretia: the dagger in her breast, and in the act of heroic self-destruction: What resolution! what a spirit has the great artist thrown into those eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Yes, she had a devil of a spirit: She stabb'd her∣self in a pique upon being cross'd in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: You prefume on our ignorance; history, I believe, assigns more elevated motives for Lucretia's death.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Very likely; there were great pains taken to smother the story; but 'tis as I tell you—I had it from a near relation of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Ridiculous! Do you observe that picture, Madam; 'tis a melancholly story, very finely told by Poussn: It is a view of Marseilles at the time of the plague, with a capital figure of the good bishop in the midst of the groupe.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK
SP.P: Bishop, Madam! that person which you look up∣on is a physician, and the people round about him are his patients; they are in a desperate way it must be confest. Do you see that angry figure in the corner; he is a gamester: he is picking lead out of loaded dice to run into bullets, to fire through his own head: 'Tis no bad moral.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: You are infinitely kind to favour us with these anecdotes: If you are thus gracious to all strangers, the world will edify abundantly. But we won't put you to the trouble of explanation—we are not en∣tirely ignorant—tho' your collection may be the best we have seen, it is not absolutely the first.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Belike then you are a painter, as well as the lady I visited just now.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: In the presence of such masters as are here assmbled, I cannot call myself a painter; in my own chamber I sometimes persuade myself I am.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Yes, I am told it is an art which ladies mostly practise in their own chambers—What say you to that picture over the door? 'tis a merry conceit.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: It is the colouring of the Venetian school: I should guess it to be Tintoret.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Oh, you are quite out of the story.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: She is speaking of the master: The story is plainly that of Actaeon, and no bad moral; he was turn'd into a stag, by the goddess of chastity, for his im∣pertinent curiosity.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Excuse me, Madam, you mistake the moral—That gentleman with the antlers on his head, is a city husband, the principal lady in the show is his wife; she wears a crescent on her forehead to signify she is a dealer in horns; her companions are a groupe of city Madams: The painter drew them bathing to shew the warmth of their constitutions.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Upon my word you have a great deal of wit, and you have a fine collection of paintings; but one capital piece is wanting.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: And what is that, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Modesty: It will be an excellent companion to your Lucretia.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: But who shall I get to sit for the likeness?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: You will find it admirably painted by the same master. Come, Madam, it is time for us to be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: You are not for the city-end of the town, I conclude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Our home is in the city.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Permit me to conduct you thither; I have a coach in waiting, and am bound to New Broad-Street, if you know such a place.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Intimately; but we have a carriage of our own.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Can there be any attractions in the city to engage Mr. Manlove's regards?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Oh, yes; an assignation, Madam: I am loth to disappoint a fond girl.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: 'Tis charitably consider'd.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Nay, I don't know but I shou'd be inclined to take her for better for worse, if it was not for one cir∣cumstance in her disfavour.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: May I ask what that may be?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: She has a devilish itch for painting: I shou'd ex∣pect to have all my gods and goddesses taken down to make room for her vulgar friends and relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Ay, that wou'd be a sorrowful exchange to my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Yes, have a care of that same painting girl: My life upon it she will slip through your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Why I have my eye upon that honest gentleman in the picture, with the stag's-horns, I must own—Who shall I tell her gave me the caution?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: No matter; when you see Miss Fairfax you'll re∣member me.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Fairfax! the vengeance: How came you to guess her name?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, there is but one painter in the street, and she, I believe, will remain there; your collection is safe; she will trouble you with none of her perform∣ances, none of her daubings, take my word. Your most obedient—Let us make haste home, and be ready to receive him: Vain, senseless coxcomb! how I shall enjoy his confussion!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: A good lively wench, but the devil of a tongue! I'll run and hand her to her coach.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: STILL I protest against your project; we shall reap nothing from it, take my word, but shame and disappointment; however, to convince you that my fears are not for myself, I am prepared and shall go through with it, as you desire.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: My life upon't, he takes the bait this time.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I doubt it, but no matter: Sure it's time that he was come. Hark! who is that? look out.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! Mrs. Stapleton and Miss Laetitia.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: What's to be done now?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P:
We've nothing for it, but a desperate sally; slip the back-way down with me, and let us both go out
and stop young Nightshade: We can take him to my lodgings and prevent an interview that must be fatal.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: It is too late to deliberate: Come on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Come, my dear Laetitia, you think of this affair too seriously: You cannot much regret a man you never saw before.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: It's true; and yet, with shame I own it to you, I am mortified severely. Was there ever such a dis∣appointment?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Either he treated us with inexcusable contempt, or is profoundly ignorant. Did you remark the ridicu∣lous observations he made on some of the pictures?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Yes; but I set that down for mistaken wit; in short, his manners are of the vulgarest cast. Are these the fruits of public education? Is this the finish'd gentleman? the scholar? traveller?—His boorish brother in the country cannot outgo this: And the world to be so blinded! Oftentimes it speaks worse of a man than he deserves; it is seldom guilty of telling so many untruths in his favour.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: A gentleman desires to speak with Miss Fairfax.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: 'Tis he—Conduct him into the drawing-room; I'll wait on him immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Well, Laetitia, I need not recommend to you to treat him as he deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I must be more, or less, than a woman, if I spar'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Please to walk in here, Sir; Miss Fairfax will wait on you immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Ay, ay; I dare say she will: Egad, there's no time to be lost—Drown it, where's Dibble? I ex∣pected he wou'd meet me at the gate: If I shou'd stumble on old Crusty—I don't like the looks of the land so well as I did: Here's such a solitude, and such a ceremony—Why the plague do they make me kick my heels here? What, the vengeance! is she come again?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Your humble servant, Mr. Manlove: You scarce expected, I believe, to meet your visitor again so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: No, indeed: it is vastly beyond my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: You are punctual to your assignation, I perceive.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Oh yes; Ma'am: to be sure, Ma'am—How the plague shall I get rid of her?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: You did well to consider the poor fond girl that is dying for you.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: She has the devil of an assurance—What are these London Ladies made of?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: He is thoroughly confounded: I'll give him a chance, however.—Have you any commands for me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P:
Commands! Oh, none in life, I thank you; no commands. What won't that serve? No: She will
have her talk out at least. I hope you lik'd the pictures? Sure Miss Fairfax will come presently.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I admire your collection greatly; my expectations in that particular were not disappointed.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: I understand your insinuation, Madam; but Ladies expectations, I am told, are not always to be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: In Mr. Manlove's instance, perhaps not easily.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Really, Madam, I shou'd wish to do justice to a lady's good opinion: but your visit, I must say, was rather unseasonable, and that elderly Lady was so vexatiously in the way.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I am sorry for it, Sir: I am afraid our visit was rather out of rule.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: That's honest now; and since you own it, I must fairly say, the present is none of the most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I readily believe it—and therefore, Sir, though it is not altogether in character for me to promote a conversation of such a sort as you hinted at when we met at your own house; yet, I must observe to you, if you have any such proposal in design, it will be for both our ease that you shou'd come to the point directly.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: To the point, Madam! Upon my soul I don't know what to say to that—To be sure I did come here with a full and fixt design of offering myself to Miss Fairfax upon the marrying lay, and that, you know, at best is but a hanging kind of job; so that if I appear rather dull of apprehension, I hope you will recollect that a man cannot be very merry when he's on his road to his execution.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, be under no concern on that account; assure yourself, I have to the full as little disposition towards that state as you can have.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Well said again! but it won't take.—You are in the right; you are for enjoying your freedom.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Since we are both agreed in that respect, what occa∣sion is there for more words? I believe we may break up the conference.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: As soon as ever you please; I am by no means for delaying you.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I wait your motions, Mr. Manlove, I'm here at home.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: You cannot be more so than I am.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Indeed! this conduct, Mr. Manlove, is so opposite to all that I expected from you, that I'm cast into astonishment. Upon what reasons, or from what ca∣price you've chose to take it up I know not; natu∣ral it cannot be to any man. However, Sir, I'll take you at your word, and, for a moment, will suppose you more welcome in this house than you really are, and leave you in possession of it.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Come, come, well off! I've bolted her at last. 'Fore George, I begin to be tired of my plumes: Every man's best in his own coat and his own character: Plain Jack and the country, wou'd have suited me bet∣ter: There are so many demands upon a fine gentle∣man, that nobody but a fine gentleman can tell how to avoid them.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Ah, Master Jacky, keep close. Yonder's your old Dadd at the street door in a notable primmuniry.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Death and the devil! how shall I break pasture without his seeing me?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P:
Never fear it; he has a job upon his hands will
tether him for one while. Egad, I hope they'll trea him with a ducking.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: What is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Nay, nothing out of course; he has crack'd the news-man's noddle for winding his horn in his ear; he pretends to have delicate nerves, you know; and so the fellow rais'd a mob upon him, that has drove him into cover, and they are now baying the old buck at the door. Ay, yonder he is; you must keep close till he's off his stand.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Have an eye upon the door—I hope they will scare him soundly; it may save your scull and mine many a hard pelt. But, Gregory, who is this fine Madam I've been talking to? Lawyer Dibble sure has not put me on a wrong scent: They introduc'd her to me as Miss Fairfax; are there two Miss Fairfaxes, as well as two Mr. Manloves; a false one and a true one?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: What shall I say now?—Oh, yes, there are two ladies of that name; but this is only a cousin of the other; a kind of hanger-on in the family.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: A hanger-on, do you say?—Keep your eye upon the door—Why, she's better dress'd, and a finer wo∣man than her I'm in pursuit of.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Ay, ay, but your's has the fortune; Dibble's Miss Fairfax is the girl for your purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: But where is Dibble and his Miss Fairfax? I have danc'd attendance here a pretty while; what am I to think of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P:
What are you to think of it? why I'll tell you; this young lady, d'ye see—Now don't you go about, Master Jacky, and say that I told you, but this
young lady here, that you have been talking to, is—Hark, sure your father's coming.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: I hear his foot upon the stairs; my bones ake at the sound of it.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Quick, quick, down the back stairs, and away for your life; so, so; that's well.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why, Gregory, rascal, hangdog! what's become of you? run quickly down and drive those bawling fellows from the gate.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: A herd of wolves as soon; they'll eat me up alive. O lack-a-day, Sir, you know little of a London mob.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Go down I tell you, Sirrah, and disperse 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Why, Sir, 'tis more than my Lord Mayor can do: There's a man knock'd o' the head they say, and till there's another or two to keep him company, they'll never be at rest: Leave 'em to fight it out.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Leave 'em! why blockhead, it is me they follow: Nothing else should have driven me into this house again.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: O Gemini, have you been knock'd o' the head?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why no, you fool, 'tis I have done the mischief; but the most patient man alive cou'd do no less.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, if you have been playing the same tune upon their noddles, as you do upon mine, these London sculls won't bear it; they are as brittle as a Shrewsbury cake.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Hey-day, friend Andrew, what is all this noise and outcry?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I think the devil's in the people, you shall hear—As I was coming down the street, in meditation on the parson's pidgeon-house, a rascally scaramouch, in a short jerkin, with a cap and feather on his noddle, winds me a damn'd blast on his post horn, point-blank into my ear, flourishing his newspapers full in my face at the same time: Now as there are no two things I hate on earth like newspapers and noises, so I could not well avoid giving him a gentle remem∣brance with my cane upon his crown: The casket gave a curfed crack and down tumbled the politician: Instantly the raggamuffins collected, and I took refuge here in your court-yard.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Nay, if you have silenc'd the Morning Post, you had better have drag'd the speaker out of his coach, and beat his brains out with the mace. Do you con∣sider how many enemies you make by stopping the circulation of abuse? 'tis as necessary to the city as the circulation of cash.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Go down I tell you, fellow, and make up the matter with a dram; 'tis as much as any newspaper-head is worth in the kingdom; bid him not talk of damages; if my cane has split his scull, 'tis no more than his plaguy post-horn did by mine: He was the aggressor.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Hark'ee, you'll find the matter settled, but it will not be amiss to frighten him a little; you know how to manage it.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Most daintily I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: O, Mr. Nightshade, here's a piece of work!—this comes of being in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: A sober citizen, a pains-taking industrious soul—

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: father of a family—eight helpless babes—I fear you've given him his last blow—Dear Sir, assist us!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Last blow! what matters that, when he gave me the first!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Well, well, heaven knows, but anger is a frightful thing; it turns a man into a fury. Defend me, I say, from a passionate man.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: And yet, madam, give me leave to tell you, you are enough to make one: Is it nothing to have our nerves lacerated, our whole fabrick shook to atoms by these horrid noises! The law should provide against such nuisances.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: The law regards breaking of heads as the greater nuisance of the two—But here comes Gregory—Well, what has become of the postman?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: He has sounded his last horn! You may sleep in quiet for the future. I tender'd him the dram your honour was so good to offer; but his teeth are closed, he can't accept your favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: O horrible, you've kill'd the man!

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: What say the standers-by on the occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: They give him an extraordinary character; they say he deliver'd a hand bill and sounded a posthorn better than any man in all the bills of mortality.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA
SP.P: Thanks to Mr. Nightshade, he is likely to make a figure in the bills of mortality still—did you see the wound?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: A perilous gash, I'd not have such a star in my forehead to be the richest alderman in the city of London.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: 'Tis a pity but he had been one, for then his horns might have warded off the blow.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: If I was your honour I would be looking out for the crowner; it will be well done to touch him pretty handsomely before he calls a quest upon the body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Has the gentleman thought of any witnesses?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: You must have a steady set to prevent accidents, unprejudic'd, impartial men, that were not present at the affair, these people will never do: For my part, if you think of subpaenaying me, you are a lost man, if I was once to shew this head of mine in open court you wou'd be condemned upon the face of it.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, rascal, I don't believe a word you say: I'll go down and be satisfied with my own eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Hold, hold, friend Andrew, I'll not suffer it; they'll tear you piecemeal: Stay where you are and let me see if I can't quiet 'em; they know me and will credit what I tell 'em: If it is as Gregory says I'll send him to the hospital; we'll save him, if it's possible.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Thank you, Master Stapleton, thank you heartily. That's friendly howsoever.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Dear Madam, follow Mr. Stapleton, and persuade him not to let him off; he must be made to feel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: I think he should, and will leave him in your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Ah, Mr. Nightshade, will you never be brought off from this unhappy temper? You see the dismal effects of it; you feel them; I perceive you do: Your compunction is severe; I pity you—your situation brings the tears into my eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: It's more than it does into mine; I tell you it is all a collusion to extort money; and this rogue of mine falls in with the plot. Stapleton will tell another story.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I am afraid not; prepare youself for the worst, and consider what attonement you can make to a discon∣solate widow.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Spare your pity, young madam, you don't yet know how easy most widows are to be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: To be sure, madam, his honour is in the right to bear up as they say, but it will be a trapan at least: The china riviter at next door is a knowing man in fractures, and he says his scull will never ring well again so long as it is a scull. Oh, Sir, what will poor dear Master Jacky think of this? He's in the country, lord love him, and little dreams of this mishap; I fear 'twill break his heart.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, you blockhead. Well, Mr. Stapleton, you've seen the man.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: I've seen the man, and pacified the mob.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: That's well; and it all proves a false alarm?

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd say so—but we must hope the best.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: How! what! sure he is not in danger? This fel∣low's report I did not regard; your's alarms me.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Compose yourself, however; the symptoms, indeed, are unpromising, but I have put him into good hands; he is convey'd to the London Hospital. Be a man; I am sorry to see you so uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Dear Sir, 'tis natural; the worst of men have mo∣ments of compunction; it is not to be supposed that Mr. Nightshade, though fatally addicted to passion, is totally devoid of human feelings.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I beg you'll be so kind to leave me; I shou'd wish to have a minute's recollection. Gregory, you may stay.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Laetitia, I begin to pity him.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Have patience: let him chew the cud of reflection. Remorse, sometimes, like an advertising quack, will make great commotion in a man's constitution; but repentance is the regular physician, which by slow but steady means, conducts the patient to his cure.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Gregory!

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Your honour! How sanctified he looks! as who shou'd say, Gregory, give me a good word on my trial.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I'm thinking, Gregory, of this accident.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Well, Sir, and how do you like it?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why, I'm in hopes it will blow over; I think they'll hardly prosecute, and if the worst shou'd hap∣pen, they can make nothing of it, but chance-medley or manslaughter; nothing else, Gregory: So there's little to fear from the law. But as I am a man, who have always enforced the law against other people, d'ye observe me, and consequently made enemies amongst the wicked; I shou'd think, honest Gregory, you might stand in my place, and I'd be sure to bring you off, and reward you into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, a trifle; I shou'd be proud of being hang'd in the service of so good a master; but I'm afraid there were too many people present, and 'twou'd be gross presumption to suppose any body cou'd mis∣take me for your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why certainly that is a hard pill to swallow; but what is to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: Make over your estate to Master Jacky, and fly your country: What if I run to the French walk, and take you a passage in the Boulogne Pacquet? I may be in time to secure the cabbin before any other malefactor has taken a birth in it.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Malefactor! prythee let me hear no more of your advice, it is but wasting time; I must have better counsel; and tho' brother Manlove has not pleas'd me in the matter of the pigeon-house, yet he's a good man in the main, and understands his business; run to him, d'ye hear, and desire him to repair here directly, upon a pressing concern; I know he'll not refuse assistance when I really want him.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: I'll go directly—This is lucky.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: And d'ye mind, leave me to open the affair to him; say nothing of the accident.

SP.SPEAKER: GREGORY.
SP.P: No to be sure; a likely matter, truly.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I wish I had not smote him quite so hard; and yet I shou'd have thought no mischief cou'd have follow'd; I've struck that clod-pate twice as hard, a hundred and a hundred times; 'tis that has spoilt my hand: it is surprising what some heads will bear; I wou'd I was with my poor boy in the country; what evil genius brought me up to this curst scene of mischief and mis∣chance? Dear fortune, rescue me from this one scrape, and let me scramble out of the next as I can.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Now, Sir, be pleas'd to favour me with your com∣mands.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I am to solicit you in behalf of Mr. Manlove, that he may be allow'd the honour of making him∣self known to you.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: That is done already: I am no stranger to Mr. Manlove, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: So, so: she has discovered me—Well, Madam, if Mr. Manlove is already known to you in his as∣sumed character, may he not hope to improve that acquaintance in his real one?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: The character he has assumed, I must fairly own to you, gives me no favourable opinion of his real one: The shallow devices he made use of to impose on my understanding, when he thought himself secure from a discovery, betray a disingenuous mind; and I must believe, that no man wou'd descend from the character of a gentleman, who was not wanting in the requisites that go to the support of it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I've made myself a precious blodkhead: This mummery of the painter has disgusted her.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: As to his pretended taste for painting, I will not affect more skill than I possess, but I will venture to say, that either he is ignorant of the art, or presumes upon my being so.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I'm fairly trapp'd: I must be prating of what I did not understand—I will not offer much in Mr. Manlove's behalf, Madam; but as to his skill in painting, you will be pleas'd to consider him not as a professor, but a lover only of the art.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: A lover, Sir! that is the last character I shou'd wish to consider Mr. Manlove in.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I perfectly understand you, Miss Fairfax: You have said enough: Mr. Manlove understands you: I believe I need not explain myself any farther.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: No, the case is perfectly clear; and I flatter myself you think I have been explicit on my part.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: There can be no complaint on that score. Nothing now remains for Mr. Manlove, but to lay aside, as soon as he is able, every thought, each hope that had Miss Fairfax for its object.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: 'Twill be much for my repose

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Rely upon it, then, your repose shall never be disturb'd by Mr. Manlove; never—Adien.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Your servant—He's piqued, and it becomes him.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: If ever you see him here again, say I have deceiv'd you—let me bear the blame: Your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Good day—I shall depend upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Set your mind at rest; I'll die before I break my word: Your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: How wou'd this man plead in his own cause! Ah, why wou'd fortune not concert with nature, and either give the wealth of Manlove to his merits; or purchase out his merits to bestow on Manlove's wealth?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Where can this provoking cloak be laid? Every thing is in train, and there is not a moment to be lost—Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Lucy! whither away so fast?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I declare I did not see you, Madam; I thought you was in your own room.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: But where are you running to, Child?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Only stepping out a little way.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Stepping out! whither?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: To my brother Dibble's.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Upon a little family business, that's all. I cou'd have sworn you had been with your gentleman in the painting-room.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: My gentleman! who is it you call my gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Humph—I'll show her that I am in her secrets; it will keep her out of mine. (aside.) I thought you was with Mr. Manlove; I left you together.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Mr. Manlove! what is this you tell me?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Nay, Madam, don't be alarm'd, I am no tell tale; and though I knew Mr. Manlove in his painter's cha∣racter, nobody shall be the wiser for me, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: As sure as can be it is so! what a discovery! (aside.) Well, Lucy, I find you are in the secret; you know the real Mr. Manlove; but pray tell me who is the pretended one? I have been received at Mr. Man∣love's house, and visited here, by a young man who calls himself Manlove: Who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Oh, dear Ma'am. don't you know him?—I wish I don't get into a scrape, but there is no going back—(aside.) It is young Mr. Nightshade out of the coun∣try, Ma'am; he is come up incog, and is afraid his father shou'd discover him, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Is that all? I shan't take your word for that. I suspect there is more in the plot than you have re∣lated. If this young man is afraid of being seen by his father, what brings him hither? Answer me that?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Madam, I—I—I can't tell what brings him hither.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Lucy, don't equivocate; for I will know. I saw him leave the house just now with your brother, you are following in great haste; upon family business you pre∣tend; but I suspect upon no fair errand: Confess to me, for you shall not stir to your brother's 'till you do.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: As you will for that, Madam, but I cannot endure to be suspected, and I will confess to you when I have done crying.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Do so, you had best.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Why then you must know, that Mr. Manlove, that is, I mean Mr. Nightshade, that calls himself Mr. Manlove, is fallen monstrously in love with—

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: With whom?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Me, Madam.—Vain creature! I know she thought it was herself

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: And you believ'd him, did you?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, I believ'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Well, and what did he do then?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Nay nothing, Madam, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Come, come, Lucy, but I know it is not all: You have given him your company, as you call it, have you not? and you are now going to meet him at your brother's, are you not?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: No—yes—but if I am, it's all in fair and honest way of courtship: Oh, if he was to go for to offer any thing unhandsome to me, I should tear his eyes out. Nobody can say I have the least speck or flaw, no not so big as the point of a pin, on my reputation. It would be the death of me—I would sooner part from my life than my virtue; he has promis'd—

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: What has he promis'd?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: To marry me.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Marry you! ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Ay, I knew the jealous thing could not bear that; she will burst with envy.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Hark'ee, Lucy; I commend you for the honesty of your confession, run into my chamber; Mr. Staple∣ton is coming this way, and will interrupt us: Com∣pose yourself, and we will talk over the affair at lei∣sure. (Exit Lucy.) Happy, happy revolution! What a ridiculous mal-entendu had I fallen into! Oh how deliciously I will torture this fine gentleman-painter for his contrivances!

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: COME along, Squire, the lady is expecting you at my apartment. Every thing is in train, and 'twill be your own fault now if you are not the happiest man in England.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Hold a moment, Dibble, hold! My brother's coming and I can't resist the pleasure of a little natural exultation.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Perverse, vexation! Are you mad? By heavens you'll lose the lady—and what is worse, by heavens she'll loose the gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: So, Jack, I hope your frolick's at an end: you've been disorderly in your cups I find.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Where did you hear that?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Where I least wish'd to hear it; at Mr. Stapleton's; Miss Fairfax told me.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Miss Fairfax told you, did she so? Miss Fairfax was not very angry when she told you, I shou'd guess: You did not find me greatly out of favour, did you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: In truth I had so little occasion to boast of my own reception, Jack, that I did not give much attention to what she said of you.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: That's honestly confessed however: So your recep∣tion was but cold, and you have drop'd all thoughts of a connexion I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Intirely: I've received my peremptory dismission.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Poor Charles! you are dismiss'd? Your person, genius, equipage, estate, all stand you in no stead? Another is preferr'd before you—perhaps some country booby like myself; and don't you wish you knew the happy man?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: What are you at? you'll ruin all.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: I shall burst if I don't tell him—Brother, I believe I cou'd direct you to the man that's done all the mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I give you credit, Jack, for that: I do believe you've done me all the mischief in your power.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Who, I? Oh dear, you flatter me; a country whelp supplant a travell'd gentleman like you? im∣possible—and yet—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: What yet?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: This witness on my finger here would stagger some folks; I am apt to think Miss Fairfax means to wear it in good time.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: A wedding ring! you must excuse me, Jack; I want credulity for that.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Just as you please; I bought it for her wearing, and measur'd her finger for that purpose, and did in∣tend with the parson's help to put it on with that design.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Will nothing stop your mouth? By heavens I'll throw the matter up.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: You! you marry Miss Laetitia Fairfax!

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Dear 'Squire be persuaded, and come away.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Hold your tongue I tell you—I, I, and not the ingenious, learned, travell'd Mr. Manlove; here's a witness that will vouch for what I say. (Dibble offers to go.) Where are you running?—come back. Tell my brother what you know of Miss Fairfax's partiality for a certain, insignificant, ignorant fellow, call'd Jack Nightshade.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: For shame, Sir, you should not talk of lady's favours.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Your friend is cautious you perceive.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Hang him, he's so by habit; he's a lawyer—but speak out: You are come to fetch me to Miss Fair∣fax, and Miss Fairfax is at your lodgings, and I am to be the lady's husband, and the bill is a true bill, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: It is.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Errors excepted—You forgot your caution. This can never be. Hark'ee, Sir; a little cross examination if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: As much of that as you think proper. He's us'd to that sport; he'll dodge like a rabbit in a warren.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: You say the lady is at your lodgings: Answer me, what lady?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Sir, I believe—what lady?—that's your question—what lady is at my lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Ay, Sir, without equivocation,

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I am not upon oath in this business; nor am I obliged to ascertain the identity of people's persons; but the lady at my lodgings I take to be Miss Fairfax.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Does that satisfy you? Brother, I thank you for your coat; it has made an impression you perceive.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Have a little patience—You take her to be Mifs Fairfax?—describe her person.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: I never meddled with her person, Sir; that's not for me to do.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Is she fair complexion'd?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: I think so.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: I can't say I do.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Light hair, or dark?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: My eyes are none of the best, but I think Mifs Fairfax's hair is white.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Black as a crow, by Jupiter.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Tall, or short?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: I never measur'd her but, I take her to be tall.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Death and the devil, why you're drunk! Fair, tall, light-hair'd! why she's a little, dapper, dusky damsel, with a poll as black as—

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Hark'ee, Sir, a word in your ear.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Blown, as I hope to be a judge!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: You have a sister answers this description: You're discover'd and a villain.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Hold, hold, no closeting of witnesses.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Good Sir, be not offended. Mr. Nightshade first borrow'd your name, and my sister to keep up the jest, made free with that of Miss Fairfax—nothing but a frolick.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: What do you tell me? did my brother take my name in any interview with Miss Fairfax?

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: Certainly, Sir; she calls him Mr. Manlove at this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Away; your news has saved your ears, away.

SP.SPEAKER: DIBBLE.
SP.P: 'Egad we are all blown up: I must go and tell Lucy to make her peace.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: How now; what's this? Hollo! where's Dibble running?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Your humble Servant, Mr. Manlove—Take my name, my credit from me, Jack? It is too much. You must be saved however.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: I must be satisfied. Is this fair dealing? Where is Dibble gone?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Let him go where he will; he has made a fool of you.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Yes, but I'm not a fool to take your word for that; so let me pass.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Nay, Jack, but hear reason—

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Yes, and while you are reasoning, I shall lose the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I say the lady; have a care she does not prove the lady's maid.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: The maid! ah, brother, I'm too cunning to take that upon trust. You have raised my curiosity how∣ever, and I will know the truth—So let me go, for go I will, and that's enough.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: A match, we'll start together. My happiness is sure as much concern'd in this discovery, as your's.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I should think, brother, there's no danger but a jury will see the action in this light.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: 'Tis hard to say; juries are ticklish things; the law will look to the motives: If it shall appear that it was done not from the wickedness of the heart, but from the sudden heat of the passions, a jury will bring it in Manslaughter.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Well, and don't all the world know there's not a more passionate man living than myself?

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: You have sometimes told me I was passionate; I never heard you say as much for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: But if there was no malice in the deed, how can it ever be deem'd murder?

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Malice is threefold: First, malice express; secondly, malice implied; thirdly, malice prepense: Of each in their order—

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Pshaw! pr'ythee, what avails describing any, when I've none of all the three?

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Had you no quarrel then before the act?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Quarrel! why no—or if I had, 'twas only a few words.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Is that the cane you struck him with?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: This is the twig; I call it nothing more.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: I doubt the law will construe it a weapon of offence.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: And pray now was not his a weapon of offence? I believe the whole town thinks it such, of great offence; sick or well, there's no repose for those horns. What I did was in self-defence.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: I fear 'twill not be thought so: If indeed you had any wound to shew whereby the violence of the battery might be proved—

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Wound! why I have a wound as bad an one as his; only mine lies within side of my head, and his without: He has broke the drum of my ears.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: What do you talk of ears? if you had been happy enough now to have lost a finger, an eye, or a foretooth, it would have been the loss of a defensive member, and a mayhem at common law.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Well, brother, be so kind to tell me what I am to do.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Repent.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why so I will, provided you say nothing about the matter, and my country equits me upon trial; but if I am to be punished for my faults, what signifies repenting of 'em into the bargain?

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Well, Andrew, I must tell you there is yet a way of getting honourably out of this affair, provided you will bind yourself to me, never to lift your hand in wrath against a fellow creature.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why no, to be sure I shan't; I thought all sculls were as hard as Gregory's.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Come; you must have done with Gregory's; nay, I wou'd not alone exempt man from your fury, but beast likewise: Cruelty must not be practised in any shape: Nature must not be wounded in any of her works. Promise me this upon the faith of an honest man, and I'll redeem you from this scrape.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Look'ee, Brother, I am sensible of the folly of it, but as it's impossible to say where temptation may lead, there lies the fatal weapon; use it who will; I'll never take another stick in hand, till I'm obliged to go upon crutches.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Say you so, then I'll cure your broken head in an instant. Come with me, and you shall see what dispatch I can make upon occasion.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV3.STAGE: LAETITIA is discover'd painting; LUCY attending; a layman placed at some distance.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: These touches come off well; this last sitting was a good one: Methinks I never was in better look. Lucy, what say you? is it like?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Like, Madam! 'tis alive; 'tis Mr. Stapleton himself.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Is the servant gone for his cloaths to dress the lay∣man? I'll positively rub in the drapery now I'm about it. Well, child, I've turn'd this matter in my head, and I believe I must forgive you; there's no holding out against contrition; I believe your brother was to blame—so this painter then is Mr. Manlove?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Yes, madam, and a lovely man he is; if you please to remember, I told you so the first moment I saw him; so genteel, so well-bred, so perfectly the gentleman. Oh, here comes Thomas with the cloaths—shall I help to put 'em on?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: So, so! that's right—let the arm fall naturally—it's very well as it is—Now turn the layman with its side to me—no, t'other way—a little more. Stay, let me do it myself. Now stand away—that's it.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Have you any further commands, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: No; yes. If the young gentleman who was with me this morning should call again, shew him up hither.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: The painter?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Yes, the painter, as you call him.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Madam, he is this moment come into the court∣yard.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA
SP.P: Indeed! then do as I bid you. (Exit Ser.) So, so, he has found out the mistake as well as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, give me leave to go and shew Mr. Manlove hither.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Do so, Lucy, do so—What a flutter am I in!—but, hark'ee, don't give him any intimation that I know him. (Exit Lucy.) This is happy! I am such a gainer by this revolution that I cannot find in my heart to be angry with the girl—That ever I shou'd be the bubble of so gross an imposition! Hark; he's coming. I'll pretend to be at work! tho' I am so confused I don't know one colour from another. O heavens, how charmingly he looks!

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I ask a thousand pardons; I entreat I mayn't dis∣turb you.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, don't mention it: You see I use no ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: You're infinitely obliging. I have ventur'd once again, Miss Fairfax, to intrude upon your patience.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: As often as you please; you're always welcome here. Come hither—I must have your judgement. How do you like what I have done?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: All that you do is well; but you'll forgive me, I am full of other thoughts, and wish to lose no mo∣ment of this happy opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Pish! I must have you flatter me: Sit down—This drappery puzzles me—Sit down, I say: Your modern habits are so stiff. How shall I manage it? Come, take the chalk; nay, no excuse: Though you are so smartly drest, you absolutely must assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I beg to be excus'd: my happiness is staked upon this crisis; my heart is full and must have vent.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: How can you be so tiresome? Now you are going upon the old topick, Mr. Manlove.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I must confess it is of him that I wou'd speak.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Fye, fye upon you! call to mind your promise. Hold—suppose I throw aside this ugly brown and gold, and put him in a fancy dress; What say you?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Nothing; for I am nothing: I have no art, no faculty of painting; I am an impostor. On my knees I do beseech you, forgive and hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Pray be composed, nor let your zeal for Mr. Man∣love agitate you thus. I'll save you all this trouble, by confessing freely to you, I have chang'd my mind since last we parted.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Chang'd! as how?

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: As you'll be pleas'd to hear. I think of Mr. Man∣love now as favourably as you yourself cou'd wish.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: I think the woman must be blest, whom such a man shall honour with his choice.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Indeed! I may presume then you wou'd condescend to countenance his addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: That's a home question; but I think it is not easy to deny him any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: I'm thunderstruck! The boy has told me the truth, she likes him and I am undone.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA
SP.P: What is the matter now? You seem quite discon∣certed. Is not this the very point you aim'd a? Hav'n't I confest all that you wish'd?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Oh, no! You torture me.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Man, restless man! whom nothing I can do will satisfy: Offended when I refuse your friend; when I accept him, tortur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: And tortur'd I must be: for know, most wretched as I am, it is not for a friend I plead, but for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'm free to say, I still abide by my confession: What you tell me shakes not my esteem for Mr. Manlove.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Then I have lost you; for that Manlove is my younger brother, and has won you under a fictitious name: I that really own it, am discarded.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: How purblind you long-sighted wits sometimes can be! You tell me you are Mr. Manlove; have I revok'd my opinion? You say your brother took your name; have I express'd myself in favour of Mr. Nightshade?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: O heavens! I do begin to hope—

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: You shou'd not puzzle me with such cross purposes. Will you be Mr. Manlove, and believe what I now say of him, or give that name to your brother, and hear me repeat what I lately said of him?

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Oh, let me be what you approve; I ask no higher blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: We are interrupted. See, your formidable rival! Oh, you have made a fine confusion—Come away.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P:
Hist! hark'ee! brother Charles!—He won't turn back, and I dare not follow him, for fear I run into
old Crusty's jaws: I am fain to go as warily in this house as if I was riding over a warren. Didlikins! here comes the girl at last—Oh, fye upon you, Miss, oh fye—

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Hush! hush! A truce to your reproaches—Hide yourself; your father's at my heels.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: My father! Drown it! what shall I do now?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Here, get behind this layman; stoop: stand close: I'll put the shutters to; I owe you that good turn, at least, to bring you off. Stand close!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: So, so! What's doing here? Darkness at mid-day! Your servant, Mr. Stapleton; I see you notwithstand∣ing; there you are: Fine goings on at your age: Smuggling your chambermaids in corners—Call you this fair trading? Oh, if your wife saw this.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: For pity's sake keep him off. He's coming!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Where are you coming, Sir? Pray leave the room; your company disturbs him; don't you see how ill he is?

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Poor gentleman! and so you shut out the light to make him better? Ay, let him lean upon you, com∣fort him; I dare be sworn he has need of it—Shame upon you, Master Stapleton! What you'll not speak, not you. Here comes one will make you speak, and stir too, to some tune. Here, Madam, here's your virtuous husband; here's a picture of modern con∣jugal fidelity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: A picture truly, for I think you're talking to no∣thing else: Why don't the girl open the shutters? What do you stand there for? O, ho!

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: What my old friend, conserring with the layman! Break his head, Andrew, if you please; no man∣slaughter can lie there.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: How's this! why I protest I took it for yourself; and I was scandaliz'd to see a sober citizen in such close conference with a damsel of so great temptations.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Come, brother, you have had one warning against anger, let this be a memento to guard against suspicion.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Brother, you know I can't endure advice; I see my error; that's enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Yes, but you don't see all; there's more behind the scenes; your greatest error, Mr. Nightshade, is not yet found out.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Why, what the vengeance have we here? Come out: Let's see your face. Son Jack! Furies and flames! My boy as I'm alive.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: This is judgement upon judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Which of you all have conjur'd up this plot? Oh, thou unutterably vile and sorry puppy! Hound, that I have bred to tear my heart out—Jack, Jack, Jack, for you to use me thus; you whom I've made my boast, the staff of my old age—I wou'd I had a staff, I'd beat your brains out with it, blockhead, so I wou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Hold, hold, no more of that; remember promises.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: And in that jacket too; the substance of a farm laid out upon your back: Sirrah, whence came that conjuror's coat, that scoundrel's livery? Answer me.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK
SP.P: Father, 'tis none of mine; 'tis brother Charles's.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: There, Mr. Manlove! there's your pretty gentle∣man! a fine account; the corrupter of his brother.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Be more patient, friend Andrew.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I won't be patient; I've a father's privilege to jus∣tify my passion. Hark'ee, Sir, what brought you up to town? Who seduced you hither? I suppose the fashionable scoundrel who lent you that fool's coat.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Lord love you, father, 'twas a frolic of my own: Charles wou'd have had me travell'd home again.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Was that like a seducer?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: And so I shou'd afore now, but that I fell into a kind of a love-suit here, with the young lady of this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: What do you say? a love-suit!

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: With my ward, Miss Fairfax? impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Ay, now comes my examination: I had best escape.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Hold, hold; my whole defence turns upon your testimony—Stay where you are.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Ay, let us hear; there's something in this plea: Let us hear more of the love-suit.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Nay, 'twas not much of a suit neither; it was very soon over; Miss was coming, Dibble got a licence, and I bought a ring.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Why you're beside yourself, young man.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Go on! the boy speaks well, and shan't be brow∣beat: Hear him out.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: And so, as I was telling you, I shou'd have mar∣ried her out-right, if brother Charles had not thrown a spoke in my wheel.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: See there, see there! What say you for your fa∣vorite now? Prove what you say, my lad, and I will do you justice to the extent of my estate.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Say you so, father? then it shall out: Why bro∣ther Charles, you must know, had a month's mind for the lady himself; so he pretended to persuade me that I was made a fool of, and that the girl I was going to marry was not Miss Fairfax.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: There, there you hear it now from the tongue of truth and innocence: You're satisfied, I hope. I beg the lady may be sent for in.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Sent for! a pretty joke; why there she stands.
Mr. and Mrs. STAPLETON.
Ha. ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: I'm thunderstruck.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: And so am I; for if it had not been for brother Charles, as sure as you are here alive, we had both been happy before now.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: This, this the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Ay, father, that's she: I hope you like her.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Lucy! Lucy Dibble!

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: The sister of my clerk!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Death and the devil! a chambermaid!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Oh, you insidious hussy! what can you say for yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: I am not here upon my trial, madam; that is past, and Miss Fairfax has sign'd my pardon. As for this gentleman, if I did put a little trick upon him under my mistress's name, he paid me in my own coin, by passing himself off under his brother's. The parties represented are not present; but let me stand at Miss Fairfax's side, and place him by Mr. Manlove, and I leave the world to decide which is the greatest im∣postor of the two.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Oh, you abominable little vixen!

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Keep your peace, Jack, wou'd you prove your valour on a woman?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Then by Jupiter, I'll break every bone in lawyer Dibble's skin, before this day's at an end.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Understand yourself, child; the daughter of a footman is no mate for the son of a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: To be sure: Well said, Master Stapleton!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: True, Sir, but the footman bred his daughter as a gentleman shou'd, and the gentleman gave his son the education of a footman.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Brother Andrew—

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Pooh!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Father, that last wipe was at you.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, blockhead; get you home into the country, till the soil, and be a beast of burden; 'tis what nature meant you for.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Nay, brother, blame not nature, she has done her part: 'Tis you that shou'd have till'd the soil. O Charles, you come upon a wish; your father is im∣patient to embrace you.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: Let but my father add his approbation, and my happiness shall be compleat.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: He can't withhold it. Come, throw prejudice aside; let wrath and jealousy be cast far from you: Look upon this youth; he is your son; you are the principle, but do you substitute the justice to confess my system has succeeded; it is possible you see to gain a knowledge of this world, and not be tainted with its wickedness.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHAE.
SP.P: 'Tis mighty well; but for this cub of mine I'll disinherit him to the devil; I cou'd find in my heart, to die to-morrow, for the pleasure of cutting him off with a shilling.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Lord, father, in that case a little matter wou'd content me.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Come, come, the law has made provision against that: Jack must inherit your estate die when you will.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P: Then I'll not die at all; I'll live for ever on purpose to plague him; I'll starve the whelp; he shall have nothing to live upon, but rain-water and pig-nuts.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Then, Andrew, I will keep him; he shall live with me.

SP.SPEAKER: NIGHTSHADE.
SP.P:
Say you so, brother? then I'll forgive him and keep him to myself; and since you talk of knowledge of the world, I'll shew him what it is: Come hither,
Jack: I'll go with him as far as there is water to carry us; I'll travel him to the world's end: Zounds, I'll take him out of it, rather than be out▪gone.

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: Take the last stage by yourself, dear father. Farewel, uncle; good-bye, Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Incorrigible humourist! Come my son, and come my worthy friends: Where is your amiable ward? I still have hopes this day of rancour and confusion will conclude with joy.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: And so it shall, if my persuasion can have weight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Persuasion never fails, when inclination aids it. Look, she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: CHARLES.
SP.P: And comes like hope, like spring and sunshine to the longing year, with smiles of soft complacency and love.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Ay, now your rival's gone, you think the field your own; but every hour will raise fresh rivals, for every hour will draw forth fresh perfections from a character like your's, and each demand the preference in our admiration and applause.

SP.SPEAKER: STAPLETON.
SP.P: Well said, my girl, then there's a bargain made; What need of further words?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Fye upon you, Mr. Stapleton, you distress her; you are too much in haste about these matters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Why, Dolly, you and I concluded our matter within the week.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STAPLETON.
SP.P: Longer, 'twas longer: Don't believe him, Laetitia.

SP.SPEAKER: LAETITIA.
SP.P: Excuse me, I can readily believe that hearts so fitted for each other might unite at once by mutual at∣traction.

SP.SPEAKER: MANLOVE.
SP.P: Dost thou believe it, fair one? then away with all delay! not even the law, its own parent, shall be pri∣vileg'd in this case; we'll work like shipwrights at an armament, and Dibble, as a punishment for his intrigues, shall labour double tides. If marriage ever shall regain its dignity in this degenerate age, is must be by the union of such hearts as these.
